 Federal Court 
 
 Phelan, J. 
 
 September 15, 2010. 
 
 
 
 Counsel: 
 
 Annette Mebrahtu, for the applicant; 
 
 Allen Matte, for the respondent. 
 
 
 
 Solicitors of Record: 
 
 Myles J. Kirvan, Deputy Attorney General of Canada, Ottawa, Ontario, for the respondent. 
 
 
 
 Summary: 
 
 This case is unedited, therefore contains no summary. Any footnotes found in this case will appear below end of document.

[1] 
   
 Phelan, J. 
 : This is a judicial review of a decision by a member of the Pensions Appeal Board (PAB) denying the Applicant's leave to appeal a decision of a Review Tribunal which had found that the Applicant was not eligible for disability benefits under the  
 Canada Pension Plan 
 , R.S., 1985, c. C-8.

[2] 
  As a preliminary matter, the Respondent should be the Attorney General of Canada alone. The order to be issued will contain that amendment to the style of cause.

[3] 
  The Respondent has objected to the inclusion in the record of materials not in evidence before the decision makers. Given the result, it is not necessary to deal with this proper objection.

[4] 
  To be eligible for a CPP disability pension, a claimant is required to establish that they made contributions for not less than the minimum qualifying period (MQP). As there is no issue that the MQP ended on December 31, 2001, the Applicant had to establish that she was "disabled" as of December 31, 2001 and continuously thereafter as per s. 42(2) 
 (a) 
  of the  
 Canada Pension Plan, 
 
 
 
 which requires a claimant's disability to be severe and prolonged.

[5] 
  The Applicant had initially complained of a thumb injury in 1999. Unfortunately, by 2004 she was also suffering from blurred vision, chest pains, a burning sensation throughout the body and light aversion. She was diagnosed with a delusional disorder in 2005.

[6] 
  The Review Tribunal denied the Applicant's claim because the evidence showed that after 1999, and more importantly, after December 31, 2001, the Applicant was able to work on a regular basis, at least until the time of her 2004 diagnosis. The Applicant made statements during the hearing process in 2008 which also served to confirm her ability to work.

[7] 
  The PAB denied leave to appeal the Review Tribunal's decision having found that the Applicant did not have an arguable case. The PAB relied on the evidence before the Review Tribunal that the Applicant was capable of performing gainful work when she last met her MQP and that the onset of her subsequent disorder occurred after the MQP.

[8] 
  The issues in this judicial review are: 
 
 
 
 (a) did the PAB apply the correct legal test of "an arguable case", a matter subject to the "correctness" standard of review? 
 
 
 
 (b) did the PAB err in its application of the legal test, a matter subject to the "reasonableness" standard of review?

[9] 
  While the PAB decision is brief, it is apparent that the Member identified the correct legal test.

[10] 
  As to the application of that test in this case, despite some issues of dates which the Applicant raised, there was a good evidentiary basis for finding that the injury to the Applicant's thumb did not, as of the MQP, constitute a severe and prolonged disability. The Applicant's post MQP activities and the medical opinions provide a reasonable basis for the PAB's decision.

[11] 
  The Applicant's delusional disorder is truly unfortunate, and a factor which should diminish the effect any of her statements made against interest in the Review Tribunal decision. Nevertheless, the fact remains that this disorder and other conditions occurred after the MQP.

[12] 
  Therefore, this judicial review will be dismissed without costs. 
 
 
 
 JUDGMENT

[13] 
   
 THIS COURT ORDERS AND ADJUDGES that 
  the application for judicial review is dismissed without costs. 
 
 
 
 [End of document]

statutes: Canada Pension Plan, R.S., 1985, c. C-8
s. 42(2) (a) of the Canada Pension Plan
legal_issues: Whether an administrative body applied the correct legal standard when assessing the threshold for granting leave to appeal.
Whether an administrative body’s application of a legal standard to specific facts was reasonable.
Whether evidence of an individual’s ability to perform work after a qualifying period impacts eligibility for disability benefits.
Whether a disability must be present at the end of a minimum qualifying period and be continuous thereafter to qualify for benefits.
The extent to which subsequent onset of a condition affects eligibility for benefits based on a prior qualifying period.
factual_background: An individual applied for disability benefits under the Canada Pension Plan.
The initial claim was denied by a Review Tribunal, which found the applicant ineligible.
Eligibility for benefits required establishing contributions for a minimum qualifying period (MQP) and being 'disabled' as of the end of the MQP (December 31, 2001) and continuously thereafter.
The applicant initially reported a thumb injury in 1999.
By 2004, the applicant also experienced blurred vision, chest pains, a burning sensation, and light aversion.
In 2005, the applicant was diagnosed with a delusional disorder.
The Review Tribunal determined the applicant was able to work regularly after 1999 and until the 2004 diagnosis.
The applicant made statements during the hearing process indicating an ability to work.
The Pensions Appeal Board (PAB) denied leave to appeal the Review Tribunal's decision, finding no arguable case.
The PAB based its decision on evidence suggesting the applicant was capable of gainful work when the MQP was met and that the subsequent disorder arose after the MQP.

Applicants: The applicant was 'disabled' as of December 31, 2001, and continuously thereafter.
Issues existed regarding dates relevant to the determination of disability.
Statements made by the applicant during the hearing process should be considered in light of her delusional disorder, diminishing their weight.
Respondents: The applicant was capable of performing gainful work when she last met the minimum qualifying period (MQP).
The onset of the applicant’s delusional disorder and other conditions occurred after the MQP.
The applicant did not have an arguable case for appeal, as determined by the Pensions Appeal Board (PAB).

court_analysis: The court dismissed the judicial review of the Pensions Appeal Board's (PAB) decision denying the applicant's appeal of a Review Tribunal's finding of ineligibility for CPP disability benefits.

The central legal requirement for eligibility is establishing 'disability' as defined in s. 42(2)(a) of the Canada Pension Plan – a severe and prolonged disability – as of the end of the minimum qualifying period (MQP).
The court found the PAB correctly applied the legal test for 'an arguable case' and, when applying that test, reached a reasonable decision based on the evidence.

The court reasoned that the evidence supported the Review Tribunal’s finding that the applicant was capable of performing gainful work when she last met her MQP, and that the onset of her later diagnosed delusional disorder occurred *after* the MQP.

While acknowledging the applicant’s unfortunate later-onset delusional disorder, the court emphasized that this condition arose after the critical date of the MQP and therefore did not contribute to establishing disability *at* that time.

The court considered the applicant’s statements made during the hearing process, but noted the disorder as a factor potentially diminishing the weight of those statements, while still upholding the finding that the disability did not exist at the MQP.
final_outcome: The application for judicial review is dismissed without costs.
